    About Me

    Cory Gardner

    PhD Candidate, Computer Science

    Saint Louis University

    Computational Biology High-Performance Computing Machine Learning

    About Me

    I am a PhD candidate in the Department of Computer Science at Saint Louis University…

    Computational Biology

    Developing advanced methods for genomic analysis, from de novo assembly to metagenomic profiling

    High-Performance Computing

    GPU-accelerated algorithms and parallel computing for large-scale biological data analysis

    Machine Learning

    Privacy-preserving ML, deep learning for biomedical imaging, and anomaly detection

    Research Interests

    • Computational Biology & Genomics: Advanced sequence representation methods, multimodal deep learning for integrated genomic analysis
    • High-Performance Computing: GPU-accelerated image analysis, parallel algorithm optimization for large-scale genomic datasets
    • Machine Learning Privacy & Security: Membership inference attack detection, federated learning for healthcare data privacy

    Featured Research

    Privacy-Preserving Machine Learning

    Investigating inference attacks against biomedical ML models and developing defense mechanisms

    Learn more →

    Medical Image Anomaly Detection

    Novel deep learning approaches using wavelet features and self-supervised learning

    Learn more →

    Hybrid Yeast Genome Assembly

    Chromosome-level subgenome-aware assembly revealing post-hybridization divergence

    Learn more →

    Recent News

    November 2025 I will be presenting our work "Evaluating Accuracy and Performance Tradeoffs in GPU Accelerated Single Cell RNA-seq Analysis" at the SC'25 Correctness Workshop.
    October 2025 I presented "Practical Considerations when Choosing Digital Learning Tools" for the Reinert Center for Transformative Learning at Saint Louis University.
    October 2025 I was nominated for membership in Alpha Sigma Nu, the Honor Society of Jesuit Colleges and Universities, by the SLU School of Science and Engineering.
    April 2025 I attained PhD candidate status after passing my qualifying exams.
    March 2025 Our paper "Bioinformatic approaches to blood and tissue microbiome analyses: challenges and perspectives" was published in Briefings in Bioinformatics.
    September 2024 Our paper on Saccharomyces bayanus genome assembly was published in Genome Research.
